column3: early 20th century; earliest use found in Flight International
early 17th century: from Tupi, imitative of its cry
early 19th century; earliest use found in The Mechanics' Magazine
Middle English: via Old French from Latin alienus ‘belonging to another’, from alius ‘other’
early 18th century: from modern Latin androides, from andro- + -oid

1960s; earliest use found in Ursula Le Guin (b. 1929), writer of science fiction and fantasy. Shortened from answerable, with suffix substitution, so called to contrast with wave-based communication technologies (such as radio) which are not answerable over interstellar distances within any useful period of time
mid 19th century; earliest use found in Thomas Carlyle (1795–1881), author, biographer, and historian. From any + when
Old English bēam ‘tree, beam’, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch boom and German Baum
1960s; earliest use found in Proceedings of the AFIPS Conference
Old English bāt, of Germanic origin
late 19th century (originally US): abbreviation of confidence, as in confidence trick
mid 17th century: from Latin, neuter of continuus (see continuous)

Old English cræft ‘strength, skill’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch kracht, German Kraft, and Swedish kraft ‘strength’. craft (sense 3 of the noun), originally in the expression small craft ‘small trading vessels’, may be elliptical, referring to vessels requiring a small amount of ‘craft’ or skill to handle, as opposed to large ocean-going ships
mid 16th century (originally in the senses ‘belief’, ‘credibility’): from French crédit, probably via Italian credito from Latin creditum, neuter past participle of credere ‘believe, trust’
late 17th century: from Dutch kruiser, from kruisen (see cruise)
1960s: invented by the scriptwriter Terry Nation ( 1930–97)
late Middle English (in dimension (sense 1 of the noun)): via Old French from Latin dimensio(n-), from dimetiri ‘measure out’. dimension (sense 2 of the noun) dates from the 1920s
1949: coined by George Orwell in his novel Nineteen Eighty-Four
late 16th century; earliest use found in Huloets Dictionary. From earth + -like
Middle English (in an earlier sense). In some forms from earth + man. In some forms from the genitive of earth + man

mid 19th century; earliest use found in Elizabeth Barrett Browning (1806–1861), poet and writer. From earth + side. With use as adverb compare slightly earlier stateside. With use as adjective compare earlier stateside
mid 19th century (in an earlier sense). From earth + woman, after earthman
early 20th century: from Greek empatheia (from em- ‘in’ + pathos ‘feeling’) translating German Einfühlung

late Middle English (in the sense ‘unreal’): from Old French fantastique, via medieval Latin from Greek phantastikos, from phantazein ‘make visible’, phantazesthai ‘have visions, imagine’, from phantos ‘visible’ (related to phainein ‘to show’). From the 16th to the 19th centuries the Latinized spelling phantastic was also used

late Middle English: from Old French fantasie, via Latin from Greek phantasia ‘imagination, appearance’, later ‘phantom’, from phantazein ‘make visible’. From the 16th to the 19th centuries the Latinized spelling phantasy was also used
1940s (originally US): blend of fan and magazine
1930s; earliest use found in Aldous Huxley (1894–1963), writer. From feel + -y, after movie
Old English fen(n), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch veen and German Fenn
1950s. Probably originally a transmission error for folk
1980s; earliest use found in Associated Press Newswire. From filk + -er
1980s; earliest use found in The San Francisco Chronicle. From filk + -ing
late Middle English: frequentative of flit
1960s; earliest use found in Frederik Pohl (1919–2013), writer of science fiction
late 19th century (originally in nautical use): probably from French gâchette ‘lock mechanism’ or from the French dialect word gagée ‘tool’
mid 19th century: from Greek galaktias (variant of galaxias ‘galaxy’) + -ic
Old English gæt, geat, plural gatu, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch gat ‘gap, hole, breach’
mid 19th century: perhaps an abbreviation of Jesus
Middle English: via Old French from Latin generatio(n-), from the verb generare (see generate)
1950s; earliest use found in New Worlds Science Fiction
1950s; earliest use found in Astounding Science Fiction. From genetic + engineer, after genetic engineering
early 19th century: French, literally ‘a kind’ (see gender)
mid 16th century: the Greek and Roman poets' name for the first period of history, when the human race lived in an ideal state
1960s: a word invented by Robert Heinlein (1907–88), American author
1980s: probably a blend of hologram and deck, popularized by the television series Star Trek: the Next Generation (1987–94)
Middle English: via Old French from Latin horror, from horrere ‘tremble, shudder’ (see horrid)
1940s; earliest use found in Astounding Science Fiction
early 16th century (in the sense ‘be moved or thrown with a sudden jerk’): probably imitative of the sound of feet coming into contact with the ground

Old English lēoht, līht (noun and adjective), līhtan (verb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch licht and German Licht, from an Indo-European root shared by Greek leukos ‘white’ and Latin lux ‘light’
early 20th century; earliest use found in The Frederick Post. From light + speed
late 19th century; earliest use found in The Newark Advocate
late Middle English (in the senses ‘subject to Mars's influence’ and ‘martial’): from Latin Mars, Mart- (see Mars) + -ian
1970s: from the name of a character in A Trekkie's Tale (1973), a parody fan fiction story based on the US television series Star Trek
late Middle English (in the sense ‘womb’): from Latin, ‘breeding female’, later ‘womb’, from mater, matr- ‘mother’
1970s; earliest use found in Public Opinion Quarterly
late Middle English (in mundane (sense 2)): from Old French mondain, from late Latin mundanus, from Latin mundus ‘world’. mundane (sense 1) dates from the late 19th century
early 20th century: from Latin mutant- ‘changing’, from the verb mutare
late Middle English: from Latin mutatio(n-), from mutare ‘to change’
1990s; earliest use found in Cinefantastique. From nano- + -ite
mid 17th century (as a medical term): from Latin, literally ‘mist’
Old English nǣdl, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch naald and German Nadel, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin nere ‘to spin’ and Greek nēma ‘thread’
mid 19th century: from Greek neuron in the sense ‘nerve’ + -al
1949: the name of an artificial official language in George Orwell's Nineteen Eighty-Four
late 19th century: from Latin, feminine of novus ‘new’ (because such stars were thought to be newly formed)
1949: from George Orwell's Nineteen Eighty-Four (see newspeak)
mid 16th century (referring to the eye socket): probably from medieval Latin orbitalis, from Latin orbita (see orbit)
1930s. From para- + human. Compare earlier superhuman [noun], subhuman, extra-human
1950s; earliest use found in Robert A. Heinlein (1907–1988), writer

early 17th century: from Latin planum ‘flat surface’, neuter of the adjective planus ‘plain’. The adjective was suggested by French plan(e) ‘flat’. The word was introduced to differentiate the geometrical senses, previously expressed by plain, from the latter's other meanings
1940s: from planet + -fall, on the pattern of landfall
mid 18th century; earliest use found in Benjamin Martin (bap. 1705, d. 1782), lecturer on science and maker of scientific instruments. From planet + -ography

1970s; earliest use found in The Washington Post. From pod + person, with allusion to the ‘seed pods’ in Jack Finney's novel The Body Snatchers, or any of several film adaptations based on this, in which the pods replicate and replace the population of a town
1940s; earliest use found in Isaac Asimov (1920–1992), writer. From positron + -ic, after electronic
1950s; earliest use found in Philip K. Dick (1928–1982), author. Shortened from either precognition or precognitive; apparently coined by Philip K. Dick
1940s; earliest use found in The Washington Post
1940s; earliest use found in Planet Stories. From pro + -zine
1950s: from psi, on the pattern of electronic
mid 19th century: abbreviation of public house
Middle English: from Old Norse reisa; related to the verb rear
Middle English: from Old French rai, based on Latin radius ‘spoke, ray’. The verb dates from the late 16th century
from replica + -ant: first used in the film Blade Runner (1982)
1920s: from Czech, from robota ‘forced labour’. The term was coined in K. Čapek's play R.U.R ‘Rossum's Universal Robots’ (1920)
late Middle English: from Old French, or from Latin sapient- ‘being wise’, from the verb sapere
late 18th century; earliest use found in Isaac D'Israeli (1766–1848), writer
early 20th century: blend of scientific and fiction
mid 17th century: via Latin from Greek selēnitēs lithos ‘moonstone’, from selēnē ‘moon’ + lithos ‘stone’
early 17th century: from Latin sentient- ‘feeling’, from the verb sentire
Old English scild (noun), scildan (verb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch schild and German Schild, from a base meaning ‘divide, separate’
Old English scip (noun), late Old English scipian (verb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch schip and German Schiff
late Old English scipere ‘sailor’. Current senses date from the mid 18th century

Old English scytel ‘dart, missile’, of Germanic origin; compare with Old Norse skutill ‘harpoon’; related to shoot. Sense 1 and the verb are from the movement of the bobbin from one side of the loom to the other and back
Middle English: from Old French singularite, from late Latin singularitas, from singularis ‘alone (of its kind)’ (see singular)
Middle English: from Old French escumoir, from escumer ‘skim’, from escume ‘scum’
1950s; earliest use found in The Chicago Sunday Tribune
late Middle English: perhaps imitative, or from Old French esclachier ‘break in pieces’. The noun dates from the late 16th century
1980s: origin uncertain, but often interpreted as a shortening of smegma; first used on the British television series Red Dwarf
Middle English: shortening of Old French espace, from Latin spatium. Current verb senses date from the late 17th century
1970s; earliest use found in Arthur C. Clarke (1917–2008), writer of science fiction
1950s; earliest use found in Space Science Fiction
early 20th century; earliest use found in Modern Electrics
late 19th century; earliest use found in Scribner's Monthly. From space + -ward
1930s. From space + -worthy, after airworthy and seaworthy

Middle English (denoting a flag raised on a pole as a rallying point, the authorized exemplar of a unit of measurement, or an upright timber): shortening of Old French estendart, from estendre ‘extend’; in standard (sense 4 of the noun, standard sense 5 of the noun, standard sense 6 of the noun), influenced by the verb stand
from the title of the popular science fiction film Star Wars (1977)

from The Stepford Wives, the title of a 1972 novel by the American writer Ira Levin (1929–2007), in which Stepford is the name of a fictional idyllic suburb where the men have replaced their wives with robots
1930s; earliest use found in Wonder Stories
1930s; earliest use found in Wonder Stories
1960s. From the genitive of the name of Theodore H. Sturgeon, U.S. science fiction writer + law

Middle English: from Anglo-Norman French siwte, from a feminine past participle of a Romance verb based on Latin sequi ‘follow’. Early senses included ‘attendance at a court’ and ‘legal process’; suit (sense 1 of the noun and suit sense 2 of the noun) derive from an earlier meaning ‘set of things to be used together’. The verb sense ‘make appropriate’ dates from the late 16th century

the name (said to be an acronym of time and relative dimensions in space) of a time machine which had the exterior of a police telephone box in the British TV science fiction series Doctor Who, first broadcast in 1963
1950s: back-formation from teleportation ( 1930s), from tele- ‘at a distance’ + a shortened form of transportation
1940s; earliest use found in The Hartford Courant. From teleport + -er
mid 19th century: from Latin tellus, tellur- ‘earth’ + -ian

late Middle English; earliest use found in John Lydgate (c1370–c1449), poet and prior of Hatfield Regis. From classical Latin tellūs earth, ground, also personified as a goddess, planet earth from the same Indo-European base as theal
1940s: from Latin terra ‘earth’ + the verb form
Middle English: from Anglo-Norman French, from Latin terrenus, from terra ‘earth’
late Middle English (in the sense ‘temporal, worldly, mundane’): from Latin terrestris (from terra ‘earth’) + -al
Middle English: from Old French torche, from Latin torqua, variant of torques ‘necklace, wreath’, from torquere ‘to twist’. The current verb sense was originally US slang and dates from the 1930s
late 18th century (in the general sense ‘someone or something that pulls’): from Latin, from tract- ‘pulled’, from the verb trahere
coined by John Wyndham in Day of the Triffids (1951)
late Middle English: from Old French univers or Latin universum, neuter of universus ‘combined into one, whole’, from uni- ‘one’ + versus ‘turned’ (past participle of vertere)
1949: coined by George Orwell in the novel Nineteen Eighty-Four
mid 16th century: based on Greek ou ‘not’ + topos ‘place’; the word was first used in the book Utopia (1516) by Sir Thomas More
Middle English: from Anglo-Norman French vessel(e), from late Latin vascellum, diminutive of vas ‘vessel’

late Middle English (denoting the venom of a snake): from Latin, literally ‘slimy liquid, poison’. The earlier medical sense, superseded by the current use as a result of improved scientific understanding, was ‘a substance produced in the body as the result of disease, especially one capable of infecting others’
1940s: named after Waldo F. Jones, a fictional inventor described by Robert Heinlein in a science fiction story

Old English weorpan (verb), wearp (noun), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch werpen and German werfen ‘to throw’. Early verb senses included ‘throw’ and ‘hit with a missile’; the sense ‘bend’ dates from late Middle English. The noun was originally a term in weaving (see warp (sense 2 of the noun))
1970s: popularized by the US television series Star Trek (originally referring to a faster-than-light speed attained by a spaceship travelling in a space warp)
1990s: from web, in the sense ‘World Wide Web’, and broadcast
mid 19th century; earliest use found in Martin Tupper (1810–1889), poet and writer. From world + -let
Old English wyrm (noun), of Germanic origin; related to Latin vermis ‘worm’ and Greek rhomox ‘woodworm’
1950s; earliest use found in Robert A. Heinlein (1907–1988), writer
